newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: EURO MINISTRY OUTLINES TENDER SCHEDULE.
newsitem.headline: EURO MINISTRY OUTLINES TENDER SCHEDULE.

text.p: Lithuania's European Affairs minister Laima Andrikiene unveiled on Wednesday the schedule for international bids to draft privatisation strategies for key state assets.
The preliminary schedule follows:
- Lithuanian Radio and television centre - in April 1997. The state runs 100 percent of the company. Its share capital is 57.3 million litas.
- Hotel Lietuva - in April. The state runs 70 percent of the company. Its share capital is 26.9 million litas.
- Stevedoring Smelte company - in April. The state runs 89.5 percent in the company. Its share capital is 38.02 million litas.
- Klaipeda Stevedoring company - in April 1997, the state owns 90 percent of the company. Its share capital is 128.98 million litas.
The government decided last week to boost the share capital in the company by over 120 million litas from profit reserves.
- Laivite - in May 1997. The state owns 38.2 percent of the company. Its share capital is 19.7 million litas.
- Western Shiprepair - in April-May 1997. The state runs 92.8 percent of the company. Its share capital is 83.25 million litas.
- Lithuania Sea Shipping company - in June 1997. The state runs 80 percent of the company. Its share capital is 471.3 million litas.

- Lietuvos Nafta holding of oil refinery Mazheikiu Nafta, Naftotiekis, Butinges Nafta and Lietuvos Kuras - in July or August 1997. The state owns 100 percent of the company. Its share capital is 756.15 million litas.

Within three years the state's stake can not be less than 51 percent and no less than 34 percent later on. Any other single share holder can not hold more than 33 percent of shares in the holding, the government said.
- Oil exploring company Geonafta - in September 1997. The state runs 81.3 percent of the company. Its share capital is 22.3 million litas.

- Lithuanian Airlines - in October 1997. The state runs 100 percent of the company. Its share capital is 76.5 million litas. The company handles over 55 percent of Lithuania's air passenger market, the government said.
- Aviation company Lietuva - in October 1997. The state runs 100 percent of the company. Its share capital is 27.7 million litas.
- Kaunas Aviation Company - in November 1997. The state runs 100 percent of the company. Its share capital is 17.8 million litas.
- Lithuanian Telecom - the bid was announced in March and the responses are expected before May 9.
- Baltic shipyard - in May 1997. The state runs 32.5 percent of the company. Its share capital is 34.59 million litas.
The government plans to retain its stake in the company after next share capital increase. It also said it would sell its stake on the Vilnius bourse.
The European affairs ministry said that this preliminary schedule may change.
--Andrius Vilkancas, Vilnius newsroom +370 2 22 35 17
